****UPDATE***


@ 12:52...VEOC RECEIVED AN EMAIL UPDATE FROM RHMO CANNON: 

Sit rep: I responded to an aircraft crash at 100 Marclay Rd., Williamsburg, VA. This is the James City/Williamsburg municipal airport.

On arrival James City County Fire rescue discovered a single engine piper Cherokee 180 upside down in the tree line off the runway. Extrication was conducted to remove the pilot and transport to Riverside Regional hospital. There were two occupants, one being ambulatory.

Electrical system has been secured, leaks secured. We are waiting on NTSB. Aircraft had a total of 30 gallons of avgas. It is estimated that it lost 5 gallons from a wing tank. The leak was stopped and remaining fuel is still in the aircraft. All product that went to soil, has volatilized and no product remains. The aircraft remains in a heavily wooded area off the runway until recovery this afternoon. The airport will reopen at 1300 hrs.

VEOC FORWARDED EMAIL TO SDO COX, SSDO COLLINS, LSS GROUP, VDEM FIELD RESPONSE GROUP, KING, COSTIN, GRAY....

PER TOLBERT: MECHANISM OF AIR RELEASE. THIS COMPANY DISPOSES OF WASTE EPOXY BY COOKING IT TO A SOLID. IN THIS INCIDENT A PRODUCT COMMERCIALLY CALLED  'STERLING E134 THIXO' WAS PLACED IN A 10X10X10 INDUSTRIAL OVEN AND HEATED BEYOND IT'S FLASHPOINT. FUMES CONSISTING OF BYPRODUCTS CO, CO2, WATER AND PHENOLICS BEGAN TO  ESCAPE THE OVEN INTO THE FACOTRY AND EXHAUST THROUGH AN EXHAUST PIPE INTO THE AIR OUTSIDE. THE FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS CALLED, AND RESIDENTS AROUND THE FACTORY ALSO CMELLED THE CHEMICALS. TOLBERT ADVISED THE MOST CONCERNING IS ARE PHENOLS (PHENOLICS).
